What is the Arabic novel and how has it been influenced by both European novelistic tradition and indigenous Arabic narrative forms? Visiting Professor of Literature Waïl Hassan is editor of The Oxford Handbook of the Arabic Novel, a compendium of essays, which he hopes to be released in 2016, that map the history of the Arabic novel, not only in the 22 states of the Arab League, but also in countries with large Arab immigrant populations.

A digital library of out-of-copyright, Arabic-language content has been created by NYU and NYUAD, in collaboration with the libraries of Columbia University in the City of New York, Cornell University, Princeton University, and the American University of Beirut (AUB). Arabic Collections Online is a valuable public resource for a global audience, particularly academic institutions in the region, making accessible important works of history, studies of society, religious writings, and more. Arabic Collections Online, with some 200 scholarly works already online, can be found at http://dlib.nyu.edu/aco.

Acrylic-on-canvas works in the "Re-mapping Al Fahidi" series by Emirati artist Ebtisam Abdulaziz call attention to the white spaces between the colors of rooflines, buildings, trees, and courtyards of Bastikiya, one of Dubai's oldest neighborhoods. "I wanted to draw attention to what's missing," the artist explained. "If you go there now, you see tourists busy taking pictures of the architecture that remains, wind towers and so on. But the story that's behind the place is not there anymore." The series is currently on display at the NYUAD Art Gallery.
